newsitem.title: HONG KONG: Handover themes dominate Hong Kong 1997 fashion.
newsitem.headline: Handover themes dominate Hong Kong 1997 fashion.

text.p: The Chinese flag, fast-food packaging and traditional costumes have taken centre stage in Hong Kong fashion this year, reflecting designers' "real world" preoccupations in the year of the transition to Chinese rule.

The models of Hong Kong designer Peter Lau sported symbols of rebellion at this year's "Fashion Week" shows on Wednesday, slinking down the catwalk with bright red Chinese flags masking their faces and carrying candles.
His collection, labelled Winter Under the Red Flag, is "about the period now going into 1997," Lau told Reuters.
Britain will hand the territory back to China at midnight on June 30, ending more than 150 years of colonial rule.
"The Chinese flag represents the influence of Beijing getting bigger and bigger, and is an expression of the feelings of youngsters... in a rebellious mood," Lau said.
The collection was characterised by body-revealing silhouettes but also featured thick jackets with the high collars and extra-long sleeves characteristic of traditional Chinese dress.
Chinese style also dominated the collection of Flora Pavlova Cheong-leen, whose dramatic show began with a woman with a baby strapped to her back in the style of rural China.
Her clothes were anything but rural, however -- a bright red silk tunic with high collar revealing one slinky arm, patterned with Chinese embroidery over deep green slim velvet trousers.

Even the most daring outfits -- of revealing lace or sheer materials, cut backless or paired with sultry hosiery hitched halfway up the thigh -- made concessions to tradition with a piece of antique embroidery here and there.
Pavlova refused to say her collection was focused on the 1997 handover, however, saying that theme was too "kitsch".

"I'm a costume designer so I like using the old styles and changing it into the more contemporary... what I think it really is, is about change... I think China and the Western world are merging," she said.

On the first day of the show on Tuesday designer Pacino Wan clothed his models in a dress of noodle soup packaging and a hoop skirt covered in cup-cake wrappers, which he said reflected Hong Kong people's obsession with fast food.
The designs showed "what Hong Kong people will look for in life after the handover", Wan told reporters.
Organisers say Hong Kong fashion week is one of the largest annual fairs of its kind in Asia. This year's is the biggest ever with 840 exhibitors.
The fact that it would also be the last before the handover of Hong Kong, considered Asia's fashion capital, was foremost in the minds of many there.

"This is the last fashion week before the important, historic changes in the middle of this year," Hong Kong Governor Chris Patten, who is currently wrangling with Beijing over the territory's future, said when he launched the event on Tuesday.
"The fact that we are looking at winter and fall designs for the end of the year and next year is a reminder that here in Hong Kong, life will go on being spectacularly successful," he said.
